questiontext.text: What is the melting temperature of the following PCR primer: 5'-AATCCAGGTATTCGCGAAG-3'?

answer.text: 60<sup>o</sup>C
56<sup>o</sup>C
19<sup>o</sup>C
4<sup>o</sup>C
None of the above

questiontext.text: Which of the following can increase the incidence of non-specific primer binding and subsequent non-target amplification?

answer.text: The Mg2+ concentration in the reaction is too high
The temperature used in the annealing step is too low
Primers are too small
The primer concentration was too high
All of the above

questiontext.text: What is the difference between PCR and the Sanger sequencing method in relation to primers?

answer.text: Primers are shorter in the Sanger sequencing method than in PCR because in sequencing small plasmids are used as template, as opposed to whole genomes in PCR
In Sanger sequencing only 1 primer is used, whereas PCR always uses 2 primers
In Sanger sequencing, amplification can take place in a 3' to 5' direction because there is only 1 primer. In PCR, amplification is always 5' to 3'
All of the above

questiontext.text: You design the below reverse primer: TCAGCAACTAGACCTGTAAG What is the Tm of this primer?

answer.text: 60°C
54°C
56°C
58°C

questiontext.text:
You set up 6 identical PCR reactions to amplify an 800 bp fragment of a gene from Drosophila genomic DNA. You program the thermocycler to have a temperature gradient for primer annealing of 50 to 60 °C, all other cycle conditions are the same for each of the 6 reactions. You run the products of this annealing temperature gradient PCR experiment and visualise the below gel:

Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of your results?

answer.text: Between 50-54°C the Tm of the primer is too low therefore nonspecific amplification occurs. 56°C is the best annealing temperature for this reaction, producing the highest concentration of pure product.
In lanes 2-4 there is non-specific binding due to the annealing temperature being too low. At 58°C we see the purest PCR product, therefore we should use this temperature in future experiments.

The optimum annealing temperature is in the region of 56°C. Below 56°C there is nonspecific binding which increases with decreasing temperature. Above 56°C there is a decrease in the quantity of PCR product formed due to too high annealing temperature.
none of the above

questiontext.text: You design a forward primer: GAAGTCAATTAGTTTCAA Your PCR was not successful. You think your forward primer is at fault. What is wrong with your forward primer?

answer.text: Your primer does not have a G or a C at its 3' end
The GC content of your primer is out with the recommended 40-60%
The Tm of your primer is too low
all of the above

questiontext.text: You wish to amplify a specific 350 bp region of an exon. You have leeway in the location of your primers, so long as they are within the same exon and amplify the region of interest. Below are combinations of possible primers. Which pair is the most suitable?

answer.text: F1: ATGTGCTATGACTTACTTCGR1: ATCGTATGAGCTCATACGAG

feedback.text: R1 will form a secondary structure, binding intramolecularly to form a hairpin loop

answer.text: F2: GATCAATAGCATATCCTACCR2: CAATGTAGCTCAAGGTAGG

feedback.text: There will be 3' annealing of the primers with 5 complementary nucleotides (bp)

answer.text: F1: ATGTGCTATGACTTACTTCGR2: CAATGTAGCTCAAGGTAGG
F2: GATCAATAGCATATCCTACCR3: TATGATCCTTAGCTTAATC

feedback.text: The Tm of these primers is too different with F1 being 56°C and R3 being 50°C, also the GC content in R3 is below the 40-60% recommended range

questiontext.text: Heat-stable DNA polymerases are used for PCR reaction as

answer.text: they are able to denature DNA at high temperatures
heat-sensitive DNA polymerases cannot extend PCR primers
they can start DNA replication without the help of primers
they allow the reaction to be automated as it is thermostable
they are able to extend DNA in both 3’ to 5’ and 5’ to 3’ directions

questiontext.text: You ask a 2nd year undergraduate to design a pair of primers for you to amplify an exon of the BRCA1 gene: F: AGGATACGTATAGAGATGCR: TAACTGAATATATAAGCATC Which of the below statements is true?

answer.text: The Tm's of the forward and reverse primers are very different
The GC content in the reverse primer is too low
There is a run of As and Ts in the reverse primer which may result in the dissociation of primer from the template
There is 3' complementarity between the 2 primers
all of the above

questiontext.text:
Below is a primer pair:

F: GAATCCTTAGTGCACAATGR: ATCGTAGAAGTAGCATCTTC

Which of the following statements is true?

answer.text: These are very good primers to use for PCR
In spite of them having a different Tm they are acceptable for PCR
These primers are bad because of 3' complementarity
These primers are bad because the right primer will bind intermolecularly with other right primers
none of the above

questiontext.text: Which of the following - relating to primers - is a cause of nonexistent or faint bands on a PCR gel?

answer.text: Annealing temperature is too high
3' primer end is a G or a C
A primer length of 15-18
Primer concentration is too high
All of the above

questiontext.text:
You carry out a PCR to clone a 1.5 kb gene. You also run 2 controls, a complete reaction minus forward primer and a complete reaction minus reverse primer. Below is the resultant gel:

Explain the extra bands.

answer.text: The extra bands are caused by the amplification of non-target DNA, this is due to nonspecific annealing of the primers
The band at top accounts for multimers of your PCR product assembling, whereas the band at the bottom accounts for primer dimers
The bands at the top are genomic template DNA, the band at the bottom is primer dimers
The bands at the top are genomic template DNA, the band at the bottom is fragmented PCR product due to rough treatment of the fragile DNA

questiontext.text: You want to clone a 2.5 kb fragment of the E. coli lac operon. This fragment contains 3 genes of interest. You use the following primers: F: CATAGCAATCTGTCAATACGR: ACGTACATTACGCGTAATG You have attempted the PCR several times now without luck, you have used a temperature gradient and varied the Mg2+ concentration. A lab colleague spends the morning helping you out and thinks she may have arrived at a reason for your failure to get any product. What is the reason?

answer.text: The region you wish to amplify is too large
There is 3' complementarity between your forward and reverse primers
The Tm of your forward primer is too high
Your primers are not a match in size or Tm
Your right primer forms an intramolecular hairpin 7 'bp' in length

questiontext.text:
You are using a PCR protocol from a previous PhD student in order to clone a specific 2 kb gene. You are having problems with the PCR as you are seeing nonspecific bands in the gel. You think it might have something to do with the Mg2+ concentration, your predecessor used 3 mM but it is pointed out to you that most people use 1.5 mM. You decide to carry out a Mg2+ gradient PCR experiment going up in 0.5 mM increments from 0.5 - 3 mM, below is the gel:

Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of your results?

answer.text: The best concentration for Mg2+ is 1 mM because at that concentration there is definitely no nonspecific amplification
It is better to have a higher concentration of Mg2+ in order to generate as much product possible as possible
The optimum concentration for Mg2+ is 2 mM, below that less PCR product is formed and above that there is nonspecific amplification
Mg2+ concentration plays an important role in PCR, if the concentration is too high then no PCR product is formed, whereas if the concentration is too low, then nonspecific amplification takes place
none of the above

feedback.text: Correct, the optimum Mg2+ concentration is 1.5 mM, above that and nonspecific amplification occurs, below that less and less PCR product is formed

questiontext.text: You are amplifying a 22,345 base-pair region of helminth DNA using the polymerase chain reaction. You design a pair of primers that are 20 and 22 bases in length and have identical melting temperatures. However, your reaction fails and is most likely cause is that

answer.text: your primers are not of the same length
the region of DNA you are attempting to target is too large
your primers are too short
you targeted helminth DNA; only human DNA can be amplified by PCR
The primers were designed using primer design software.

questiontext.text: Which of the following is not true about primer dimers?

answer.text: Primer molecules that are hybridized to each other because of strings of complementary bases in the primers.
Primer dimers are smaller than PCR products.
They tend to run very slow and may be a bit fuzzy at the top of the gel.

One approach to prevent PDs consists of physical-chemical optimization of the PCR system, i.e., changing the concentrations of primers, magnesium chloride, nucleotides, ionic strength and temperature of the reaction.
All of the following.

questiontext.text: All of the following regarding primers and primer designing are true except:

answer.text: Avoid runs of single bases
Primer length ideally should be 18-24 nucleotides long
Must have a G or C at the 5’ of the primer
Annealing temperature is between 50<sup>o</sup>C and 65<sup>o</sup>C
None of the above

questiontext.text:
Deduce forward and reverse primers from the following options to express CDC26 gene using pET3a expression vector and incorporating BamHI site.  Remember to include the stiffener. BamHI recognition sequence is GGATCC and CDC26 coding DNA:

1    ATGATCAGAA GGGCCCCTAC CACCTTGCAG CTCAGTCACG ACGACGTAAC  

51 CTCTCTGATC GATGACCTGA ACGAGCAGAA ACTCAAGCAG CAGCTGAATA  

101 TCGAGAAGAC AAAATACTTC CAAGGAAAAA ATGGCGGATC GCTGCACTCC  

151 AATACAGACT TTCAGGACAC ATCGCAGAAT ATCGAAGACA ACAATAACGA  

201 TAACGATAAC GATATCGATG AAGATGACGA CATGTCATCT TACAACGACA  

251 AAGCAGCCTC GGTAGCGCAC ACCAGAGTCC TCAATTCCTT GCATCTGTCC  

301 ACCGACAGCA ATACCGCCCA CGAGACGTCC AATGCAAACG ACAACCACAA  

351 CCCCTTCTAC ATCCGCGAGG AATAA

answer.text: Forward Primer 5'GCAGGATCCATGATCAGAAGGGCCCCTAC3' Reverse Primer 5'GCAGGATCCTTATTCCTCGCGGATGTAGA3'
Forward Primer 5' GGATCCATGATCAGAAGGGCCCCTAC3' Reverse Primer 5' GGATCCTTATTCCTCGCGGATGTAGA3'
Forward Primer 5' GCAGGATCCATGATCAGAAGGGCCCCTAC3' Reverse Primer5'GCAGGATCCAGATGTAGGCGCTCCTTATT3'
Forward Primer 5’ATGATCAGAAGGGCCCCTACGGATCCGCA3’ Reverse Primer 5’TTATTCCTCGCGGATGTAGAGGATCCGCA 3’
Forward Primer 5’GGATCCATGATCAGAAGGGCCCCTAC3’ Reverse Primer 5’TTATTCCTCGCGGATGTAGAGGATCC3’

questiontext.text: The forward primer is complementary to the top strand of the gene of interest and reverse primer is complementary to the bottom strand of the gene of interest

answer.text: true
false

questiontext.text: The restriction sites should be incorporated at the 5’ of the primer

answer.text: true
false

questiontext.text: The GC content of the primer should be 30-40%

answer.text: true
false

questiontext.text: The efficiency of primer annealing to the template DNA increases with the increase in primer length

answer.text: true
false

questiontext.text: After the primer anneals to the template DNA, Taq polymerase clamps to the 3’ of the primer and extends it

answer.text: true
false
